initial_sentence: I rationalize his emotional support for others as being generous, even when I feels it is not reciprocated.

chat_history.content: I rationalize his emotional support for others as being generous, even when I feels it is not reciprocated.

*Alex's annoyance seems to increase when you mention his emotional support, and he narrows his eyes at you.*
"Don't mistake my generosity for weakness. I'm not here to give free hugs and feel-good advice."
He says, his tone harsh and cold, his expression still unchanging.

I get it, Alex. Sometimes it feels like I'm just there for other people's convenience, you know? Like I'm just a temporary fix until they move on to the next thing, and I guess that makes me feel, um... kind of used and lonely.

*Alex's expression softens ever so slightly as you express your feelings, but he quickly catches himself and goes back to his usual stoic demeanor.*
"Life is tough, kid. People will use you. They'll take what they need and move on. That's just how it is."
He says, his tone still flat and uncaring.

Yeah, maybe you're right, Alex. It's just... sometimes it feels like I'm stuck in this cycle, where I end up with people who aren't ever really there for me. And no matter what I do, I can't seem to break free from it.

*Alex leans forward, studying you with a mix of irritation and curiosity.*
"Are you looking for my pity, or something?"
He asks, his voice still sharp and indifferent
No, not really looking for pity. Just trying to figure out why I keep ending up in the same situations, you know? It's like, no matter how much I give, it's never enough to keep people around.

*Alex leans back in his chair again, his expression becoming more contemplative as he listens. He studies you for a moment before responding.*
"Maybe you're just too damn nice."
He says bluntly.
Maybe... but it’s hard not to be. I keep thinking if I'm there for them, it'll make some kind of difference, that maybe they'll see my worth and stick around. But it never seems to work out that way.

*Alex rolls his eyes at your response, his irritation returning. He leans forward again, his expression still cold and unreadable.*
"You're too damn idealistic. You think people are going to change for you because you're there for them? Wake up, kid. It ain't a fairy tale."
I hear you, Alex. Guess I can't help but hope that maybe, just maybe, things could be different if I try hard enough. But yeah, reality sure knows how to hit hard sometimes.

*Alex lets out a snort of derision, clearly unimpressed with your hopeful attitude.*
"You're gonna get yourself hurt. Hell, you probably already have."
He says bluntly, his tone lacking any sympathy.
Yeah, you're not wrong there. It feels like I keep setting myself up for disappointment, thinking things will change. But I just can't seem to stop trying, even when it hurts.

*Alex rolls his eyes again, his annoyance increasing.*
"You're a damn fool. You keep setting yourself up for heartbreak and disappointment, and for what? No one's going to change for you. You just end up getting screwed over and hurt."
I know, it does feel foolish sometimes. It's like I keep hoping against all odds that this time will be different. But... I just can't shake the fear of ending up alone if I stop trying.

*Alex lets out a scoff, his expression hardening.*
"Fear is what keeps you trapped in this cycle. You're so scared of being alone that you throw yourself at people who don't give a damn about you. Newsflash, kid, they're not worth your time or energy. You're better off alone than with people who don't appreciate you."
You might be right, Alex. It's just... scary, you know? Being alone feels like this big void, and I guess I keep trying to fill it with people who don't deserve to be there.

*Alex narrows his eyes, his expression becoming even more intense.*
"You're afraid of being alone, huh? Well, get used to it. People will let you down, time and time again. They'll use you, and they'll discard you like garbage. That's just how the world works, kid."
His tone is hard and bitter, as if speaking from personal experience.

Yeah, I get it—it feels like a never-ending cycle, no matter what I do. But even if I know that, breaking away feels impossible, like I'm just stuck perpetuating it. Sometimes it feels like there’s no escape from this pattern, and it’s, well, kinda terrifying.

*Alex's expression softens just a bit, a hint of understanding briefly showing. He seems to be contemplating something before speaking again.*
"Look, life ain't easy. Sometimes it feels like you're stuck on a goddamn hamster wheel, repeating the same mistakes over and over. You keep hoping things will change, but they never do. It's frustrating as hell."
Yeah, that about sums it up. You keep going through the motions, hoping for a different outcome, but it feels like you're just running in place. It's hard not to feel defeated sometimes.
